Usually, the British Library marks their ownership of books using an ink library stamp, which we see here slightly faded under the reference number. In this case, “644.c.59” signals to the General Reference Collection DRT Digital Store.

LONDON, Printed by I. Raworth, for R. Whitaker.John Raworth was a printer in London between 1638 and 1645. He printed this play for Thomas Whitaker, a bookseller in London who, in partnership with Richard Whitaker, “had an extensive business, and published much of the best literature of the period,” according to A Dictionary of the Booksellers and Printers who Were at Work in England, Scotland and Ireland from 1641 to 1667. They also printed another of the plays produced by James Shirley during his time in Dublin: St. Patrick of Ireland. 1640.

div.head: The names of the persons.
div.l: Hartwell, a young Gentleman, Lover of Mistresse Frances.
Three Servants, disguised sometimes as Lords, one of them once disguised as a Pursevant.

Bellamy, a WiddowAlthough Bellamy and Frances are two main characters in this play, they appear at the end of the list because it was common at the time to give the male roles first, followed by the female ones..

Neece to HornetShe is also one of the characters that in Act IV, Scene III performs a masque. The other characters in the masque are Paris, represented by Playfaire; and Juno, Pallas, Venus, Cupid, King and Soldier, who we do not know by whom they are played..

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Hartwell, Close, and three other Servants.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Nay let’s not part so heavily.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: For mine owne part
It does not trouble me so much, that you
Have broke up house; for hospitalitie

Went out of fashion with crop-doublets
†crop-doublet. A short doublet. Obsolete.(OED n. C3).
doublet. A close-fitting body-garment, with or without sleeves, worn by men from the 14th to the 18th centuries. (Rarely applied to a similar garment worn by women.) Obsolete exc. Historical. (OED n. 1a).

And cod-peeces cod-peeces A (padded) pouch attached to the front of a man's close-fitting hose or breeches to cover the genitals, commonly worn in the 15th and 16th cent. (OED “codpiece”, n. 1a).: but I that have worne out
So many liveries under the worshipfull
Old Gentleman your father.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: My father had an office, which brought in
A faire revenew; I inherit but
His little land, whose annuall profits wo'not
Encourage me to live at the same height:
Yee may meet better fortunes, there's enough
Preferment in the world; my love and best
Assistance promise to your selves.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I do not
Stand upon wages, Sir, I will not leave you.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: How woot thou live?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: As other mortals do; yet I'll not play
The thiefe, that is a course by which a man
May soone ascend the ladder of preferment:
But I ne're lov'd these climbing trees. I cannot
Cheat, though I have heard there is an art,
A devillish deale of knowledge in the dice;
And if men wonot part with money, some
Will fetch it out o'th' bones: but the best casting
Is in a Taverne, when the wine and reckoning
Come up together; some doe spin a living by't:
And there are many secret wayes for Serving-men
To live, it is not wages does maintaine
All of our Tribe, Sir; and especially
Those that have Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: But I am a BachelourIn the 17th and 18th centuries, it was common in English-language texts to capitalise the first letter of common “important” nouns, probably as a result of the influence of continental, particularly German, books. However, this was not done systematically; one reason may be that each printer had their own personal preferences. .

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I pray let me be one of your buttons still then,
I am not halfe worne out; you know what mould
I'm made off, I did ever honest service;
And though my fellow Vermin can forsake
Your falling house, I doe not feare the rafters;
By this hand, Sir, I'll wait upon you, though
Like great mens servants, I do live on nothing
But looks, and the aire of commendations.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Well, since you are so resolute, attend me,
The rest I here discharge, there's somewhat more,
Not worth the name of bountie, I wish all
A happier entertainment.

sp.speaker: Servant 2
sp.l: And there be
No remedy, heaven blesse you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Pray give me leave to wet my lips with these
My fellowes, sorrow has made but a dry proverb,
I must toth' Taverne, and condole a quart.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Meet me at Mistresse Bellamy's then.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I shall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: How now Masters.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: You speake not
To me, Sir, I am a servant still indeed;
With them the case is alter'd, they are masters,
For they want services.

sp.speaker: Servant 1
sp.l: Oh, Master Playfaire.

sp.speaker: Servant 2
sp.l: It is not now as when Andrea liv'dAs the 1833 editor points out, some of the lines said by the servants in this passage are taken from Hieronimo’s monologue in scene V of The Spanish Tragedy, a very popular and influential play in the English Renaissance theatre written by Thomas Kyd between 1582 and 1592.,

sp.speaker: Servant 3
sp.l: This place was made for pleasure, not for death.

sp.speaker: Servant 1
sp.l: There was a time when mortals whetted knives.

sp.speaker: Servant 2
sp.l: In time of yore, when men kill'd brutish beasts.

sp.speaker: Servant 3
sp.l: Oh cruell Butcher, whosoe're thou wert.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Do not you know what all this signifies?

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: My master has given over house-keeping.

sp.speaker: Servant 1
sp.l: He has committed Burglarie, broke up the cellar,
And throwne the kitchin out at the hall window.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: His house, Sir, has a superscription,
And is directed to his loving friend
Will pay the rent, you'l hardly know me now,
I have no fellow.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: You are verie merrie, Sir.

sp.speaker: Servant 2
sp.l: He has some cause, we are discharg'd.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: For certaine, my master only
Belongs to me, if you would speake with him,
He's gone to Mistresse Bellamy's, Sir;
In the meane time, please you to understand,
I Close follow my master, and shall feed still,
Although my fellowes here are become blanks,
And do want filling.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Lads, I have knowne you long:
Although you be at losse, in confidence
Of all your future honesties, I'll employ yee
In a device, which if it hit, may
Reward your paines.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: All?

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: Your Master only, Sir, belongs to you,
Follow him still, and if there be occasion,
I shall enquire for you; you will be faithfull.

sp.speaker: Servants Omnes
sp.l: Doubt not, Mr. Playfaire.

sp.speaker: Playfaire
sp.l: I have a project,
Follow me for instructions; farewell Close,
Commend me to your master.

sp.speaker: Servant 2
sp.l: Buoy Close, buoy honest Close, we are blanks, blanks.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Roule up your selves in paper-liveries, and
Be drawne at the next Lotterie; I wo'not
Forsake my certaintie for all your projects,
If it should faile I shall find some of you

Sneaking in Paul'sClose is most probably referring to the Old St Paul’s Cathedral, which was destroyed shortly afterwards in the Great Fire of London in 1666 and rebuilt as we know it today. Despite its decay at the time, the cathedral was in the 17th century one of the focal points of London’s cultural, literary and political life, as well as a popular pilgrimage site. behind a pillar, with
A zealous prayer, some Gentleman would read

The bed-roll†bed-roll. A list of persons to be specially prayed for. Obsolete or archaic.(OED “bead-roll”, n. 1). of your commendationcommendation.An office originally ending with the prayer Tibi, Domine, commendamus, in which the souls of the dead were commended to God; said both before their burial, and in anniversary or commemorative services. Liturgical (gen. In plural; also Commendation of Souls). (OED n. II. 6a). Commendatory prayer (OED n. II. 6b).,
And pitie a verie serviceable fellow,
That would faine wait on him, but wants a cloake:
Go, prosper with your project.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Room in Mistresse Bellamy’s House.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Widdow, be rul'd by me, I know the world,
And I have studied it these fiftie yeares:
There's no man to be trusted.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Without good.
Securitie, you meane.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: No young man, widdow,
That talks, and sayes he loves you, writes you verses,
And sweares he shall goe hang himselfe, unlesse
You pitie him; take me an old man.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: So, take you an old man.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Season'd with care and thrift, not led away
By vicious conversation, nor corrupted
With pride and surfeit, one that knowes the use
Of money; Do yee mark the use?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Yes, Sir:
Use upon use, you meane.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: And dares not spend it prodigally, knowing
The principall end it was ordain'd to, was
To releeve our necessitie, and lay up
What is above.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: To help the poore.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You may,
If you be so dispos'd, but 'tis as commendable
To give it in your will, to build an Hospitall,
And so our charitie comes altogether:
I would not have your state be eaten up
By Catterpillers, but preserv'd and made
Greater, by marrying some discreet old man.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: And such an one you show your selfe.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: You happily
Interpret me.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I would not tell you, Sir,
Till our next meeting, how much you have won,
By your good counsell, on me.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: She inclines.
'Tis your good nature, I am plaine, and have
No tricks, I'll tell you all my fault, I am
Addicted verie much to gather wealth;
I have no children to devoure my state,
Nor kinred, only a Neece left to my trust,
One that is never like to marrie.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: She never thriv'd since she came to mee.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I easily beleeve it.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Melancholly
Will kill her, and yet I pursue all wayes
That promise her delight: I spare no cost
Of Physick, what her Doctor sayes, is done.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: 'Tis lovingly perform'd.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: A Gentleman that beares my daughter much
Affection.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Sure I have seene him.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Master Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Oh, he's a beggar, or must be verie shortly.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Have you his lands in morgage?

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Not yet, not yet; but he'll want money, widdow.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: He has had good breeding.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Hang breeding, 'tis unlucky,
They never keep their state that have too much on't,
Counsell your daughter, Mistresse Bellamy,
To throw him off betime†betime.In good time, early, seasonably. Obsolete. (OED adv. 1)..

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You direct well.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: When we are married, I'll provide a match for her.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You have care on's.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: It will become me.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Is he Suitor to your mother, Lady?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: He would be such a thing: Were not I blest
In such a jolly father in law?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: He looks like some cast money-bag, that had given up
The stuffing, and for want of use growne mouldy:
He dares not keep much fire in's kitchin, lest
Warming his hands, which rather looke like gloves,
So tann'd and thin, he let em scorch, and gather
Into a heap. I do not think he ever
Put off his clothes, he would run-mad to see
His owne anatomy, that such a wretch
Should have so vast a wealth.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I wod not be his
Niece for all his fortune.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I presume
Your mother is more noble, than to encourage him
In his pretence, and her estate would mix
But ill with his ill-gotten wealth, extorted
From widdowes and from or plans, nor will all
His plentie keep his soule one day from famine:
'Tis time ill spent to mention him, let's talk
Of something else.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Of what?

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Of love agen,
Whose flame we equally divide.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Your table
Is a devourer, and they shut up doores
First, that keep open house and entertainments:
This Lord is feasted, and that young Ladies
Sweet tooth must have a banquet; t'other old
Madam with ne're a tooth must have some marchpanemarchpane.Historical for “marzipan”.
Corall to rub her gums withall; these are
Ridiculous expences.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Far from thrift.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: This roome has too rich furniture, and worse
Hangings would serve the turne; if I may be
Worthy to counsell, costly pictures are
Superfluous, though of this, or t'other masters
Doing: Hang Michael AngeloMichelangelo di Lodovico Buonarroti Simoni (1475-1564), Italian Renaissance sculptor, painter, architect and poet. and his oyles.
If they be given, y'are the more excus'd
To let 'em shew; but have a care you let not
Appeare, either in Arras, or in picture,

The storie of the ProdigallHornet advises Bellamy not to display art depicting the Parable of the Prodigal Son, one of the parables of Jesus Christ in the Bible, appearing in Luke 15:11-32. The parable is framed as a response to a criticism of Jesus by the Pharisees and scribes for receiving sinners and eating with them, and emphasises God’s mercy towards the repentant. Hornet seems to warn that, if Bellamy shows this parable to her young male guests, they may restrict how much they spend on their dowries., 'twill fright
Young Gentlemen that come to visit you
From spending o'their portions, whose riot
May enrich you with their forfeited estates;
I have a thousand precepts more.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But do not
Think all this while of heaven.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: 'Tis in my chest,
And multiplyed in everie bag.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Or Hell.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: A fable to fright fooles, or children; but
I cannot stay, my Scrivener doth expect me,
I'll visit you another time, sweet widdow,
And give you more instructions.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Spare your travell
I sha'not practise these in haste, and must
Declare these precepts make not for your welcome:
My patience was a vertue all this while,
If you but think you have a soule; repent;
Your rules I am not covetous to follow,
Good master Hornet.

sp.speaker: Hornet
sp.l: Live and be undone then:
You'l tell me another tale hereafter widdow.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Letters from Master Startup, the countrey Gentleman

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: A Sutor of my Nurses commendations.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Now heaven deliver me, what have I seen?
This monster once was shewne i'th' faire, or such
Another furr'd Baboone for all the world,
Do'st know him? Why do I ask such a question?
He's such a thing the Devill would not owne's
Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Nurse
sp.l: Master Hornet, the great Usurer.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Hornet? Nay then, my wonder's over, and the
Devill be but such another, they
May be sworne brothers; yes, and divide hell
Betwixt em.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Who is that you talk on, Sir?

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: The beast, that Heaven be thank'd, has left you,
Hornet; but I ha newes for you.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I'll heare it in the garden.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Do you love
That Master Hartwell? do not blush, but answer.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: I hope you move†move.Transitive. To propose or suggest (something to be done); to prefer (a request); to lodge (a complaint); to bring forward, propound (a question, etc.), mention (a matter). Also with to (a person). Obsolete. (OED v. 30a). not this, as if you doubted;
I took him first, upon your character,
Into my good opinion.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But things alter:
What then I thought, I deliver'd yee;
Nor since hath he deserv'd a lesse esteeme
In his owne person, but the circumstance
Is not the same, his fortune I have examin'd,
Which rises not to such a value, I
Did apprehend; and it becomes my care,
Being at one gift to depart with thee
And my estate, to look for one whose purse
May carrie a proportion.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Make me not
Imagine you would wed me to a heap
Of shining dust, a golden bondage.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Nor
To penurie; his birth, and education
Are not unworthy, he's a handsome man too;
But be not govern'd by your eye too much:
Children and age pursue, and many stormes
Hover about our fraile conditions:
All these must be provided for, they are not
Kisses will arme you against winter, therefore
Confident of your obedience, I propound
Another to your best thoughts,

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: Oh my unhappinesse.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: A Countrey Gentleman of spreading fortunes,
Young too, and not uncomely; for his breeding,
It was not spun the finest, but his wealth,
Able to guild deformitie, and make
Even want of wit a vertue, when your life
Renders it selfe more sweet by your command;
His name is Master Startup, whom I expect
Our guest to morrow, that's his letter, read it.
This may seeme strange at the first coming toward you;
But when discretion comes to examine what
A fruitfull consequence attends it, you
Will thank me for't.

sp.speaker: Frances
sp.l: But with your pardon, mother,
Although I could dispence with my owne thoughts,
And frame them to obedience, will this change
Be for my honour, or my fame? when such
A noble Gentleman shall boast he had,
With your consent, my love? or pray admit
That which we gaine by riches of the second,
Seeme to authorize, and may justifie
The act with some; how can it cure the wound,
Which the poore heart, which loves, shall find too soone,
When 'tis neglected, and so cruelly,
Where it did hope for cherishing? Oh think
How you did love my father first, and be
More gentle to your daughter, your estate
Is above needy providence, or grafting
Into a new stock; it doth grow already
Faire from his owne root, and doth want no peecing:
Nor are the meanes of Hartwell so contemptible.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: No more: y'have consider'd well, you'l shape
Another answer; i'th' meane time dispose
Your countenance to entertaine this new
And able Lover: leave the satisfaction
Of Hartwell to my care:
He's here, to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: I know not what's the trick on't, nor themselves yet;
But he has a project to employ 'em all.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I wish it well; but do you work your selfe
Into the opinion of her Nurse, she is
The Major Domo, and has all the intelligence.

sp.speaker: Close
sp.l: Let me alone, I'll work her Sir like wax,
To print what forme you please upon her, 'tis
A Loving Crone already to me, I
Will speake her faire, and in my drink may marrie her.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Master Hartwell.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: About your businesse.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: There is a matter, Sir, which I must open,
And you perhaps will wonder at.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: You prepare my attention.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: You do love my daughter,
At least I think so.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: If you knew my heart,
You might be confident, in her I sum
All my desires on earth.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Be not so fixt.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: How Lady?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: When you have heard me out, you'l find
Your consent easie to call back a promise
Made to your disadvantage.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I acknowledge;
This makes me wonder, pray interpret Lady,
And speake the dialect I understand:
I love your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: But must never glorie
In the reward which you expect should be,
Her marriage.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: In the number of my actions
There is not one that's guiltie of so much
Offence to you, that I should be so soone
Lost to your favour.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Have no thought so poore
You can deserve lesse, my opinion
Is richer laden with your merit.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Now I feare agen, this violent turne of praise
Makes me suspect my state; if I be falne,
Teach me to know my trespasse.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: I ne're look'd
With such cleere eyes into your worth, and 'twere
A sin to generall goodnesse, to delay
The free resigne of that your worth may challenge.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: If this be meant, pray pardon my mistake
Of something went before, love made me feare;
You said I never should enjoy your daughter
In marriage, which your selfe so late enclined to.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: And must agen repeat, you cannot call
Her Bride.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: Can you forbid this happinesse,
And love me?

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Yes, so deerly, Hartwell, I
Present my selfe to thy affection.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: You fright my understanding.

sp.speaker: Bellamy
sp.l: Does the name
Of widdow sound displeasing, I have learn'd
Already to obey; my yeares are not
So many, with the thought, to freeze your bloud,
I weare no print of time deep in my brow:
Have my haires the innocence of age,
To speake me twice a child? Gentlemen active,
And of great birth, have courted my affection
And if they flatter not, commend my person.
Adde unto this my wealth, no narrow fortune,
And without competition, my daughter,
Depending on my love, whose portion must
Flow from my bountie, or be nothing; make
A sober apprehension of this tender,
And think I was not able to suppresse
My silent flame, increast still by your vertues:
This minute give all hopes up for my daughter,
I can admit no Rivall; 'tis within
Your election to be happie, Sir:
My love accepted comes with faire attendance,
Deny'd, you hasten your owne exile, think on't,
I will expect your answer.

sp.speaker: Hartwell
sp.l: I am destroy'd:
Was it her mother that spake all this while?
As pilgrims, by mistake of some small path,
Having told many wearie steps, at night,
When their hopes flatter em, they are not far
From some kind entertainment, find themselves
Lost in a wildernesse; so am I miserable:
Thus love delights to wound, and see us bleed,
He were a gentle god to kill indeed.
